results.title: Geologic time
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geological time runs on a different time scale to that which can be measured in years or by clocks. In the 1700’s, James Harvey, a Scot, was the pioneer of measuring geological time and sparked a controversy as his observations about uplift and erosion which occured in various layers of rock, was in direct conflict with the supporters of The Bible and Genesis belief in Creation. Faunal succession, the analysis of different species of fossils preserved in layers of sediments, and the use of radiocarbon dating are used to give a more exact picture of the age of the planet.

results.title: Earthquakes
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Earthquakes are evidence of the heat energy that powers movement in the Tectonic Plates. Although they cause destruction, the upheaval of the landscape to produce different elevations is ultimately benficial to the Earth. Without this variance, the power of erosion would turn the surface of the Earth into a vast desert plain. Geologists are fascinated by the measurement of earth movements and this episode examines some of these including the Richter Scale and the use of seismic waves to locate and identify the location and source of earthquakes.

results.title: Earth's structures
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geographical features like mountains are evidence of the tremendous forces that occur within the Earth such as the movement of the Tectonic Plates. The faults and folds of rocks, caused by this movement often results in vertical motion which causes rises and layering in the landscape. This episode looks at the crustal stresses, the principle of Original Horizontality, the formation of resources such as petrol and the measurement of de-formation of land structures.

results.title: Mountain building
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Mountains are evidence which enable geologists to study not only the movements of the Earth’s plates, but the composition of the interior structure of the Mantle. The Rock cycle whereby material from and below the crust is metamorphosed is also explained which enables geologists to determined how land masses are created and fused together into larger parts, eventually becoming mountain ranges. Fossil evidence and magnetic forces enable the geologist to determine the age and structure of terrain.

results.title: Plate dynamics
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Although a relatively new accepted field in Geology, the theory of Plate Tectonics, has enabled geologists to understand the ways in which the Earth’s plates move and interact. Three types of plate movements have been analysed and involve convergence of two plates, the divergence of plates and in the case of geological phenomena like the San Andreas Fault, Transformation Faults whereby the continental plates are continually slipping past each other.

results.title: The Birth of a theory
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Addresses some controversial geological theories including the theories of Continental Drift and Plate Tectonics. It was only in the middle of the 20th Century that scientists accepted that the major continents were once joined and then drifted apart due to the geological activity occuring on and beneath the Earth’s surface. The study of the ocean floor provided valuable evidence which enabled the theory to eventually gain popular support.

results.title: The Sea floor
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The sea-floor is the focus of submarine geologists. Water covers 70% of the planet’s surface and contains many of tye minerals and elements which sustain life itself. The sea-floor is largely basaltic, while continental landmasses are largely granitic. Like the landmass on the planet surface, the sea-floor has a volcanic structure, which gives rise to its varying seascapes mid-oceanic ridges, ocean trenches and fracture zones. The use of deep sea robots have enabled submarine geologists to understand how old the sea floor is.

results.title: Earth's interior
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Seismic waves, earthquakes and close study of rocks can give insight into the structure of the Earth. This episode looks at the field of geophysics in order to determine what the three composite parts which make up the Earth’s structure, i.e. the crust, mantle and core, are like. Measuring the magnetism in the Earth and its magnetic fields, looking at heat flow and measuring the Earth’s gravity are discussed. Geophysical research links the study of gravity, magnetism and seismology in order to fully comprehend the complexity of our planet.

results.title: The Restless planet
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The creation of the planets in our solar system has had an enormous impact on the geological structure of the Earth,and the existence of life on the planet. This episode examines the origins of the solar system and planets, and how the Earth and its atmosphere evolved. The Earth and its inter-relationship with the planets is also examined.

results.title: Down to earth
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Earth revealed”.
This episode introduces the vast field of geology and the work undertaken by scientists in that and other related fields. Excellent visuals stimulate the viewer’s appreciation of the Earth and a broad overview is provided on Plate Tectonics, earthquakes, seismology and the origins of our planet.
